section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: Defining relative clauses define or identify the person, thing, time, place or reason. They cannot be left out.
section.text1a: Tim is the teacher who I told you about.
section.text2a: That's the street where I grew up.
section.sectiontitle2: That can be used instead of who or which. No commas are used before and after the defining relative clause.
section.text3a: The woman who I share an office with has been in the company for years.
section.text4a: The woman that I share an office with has been in the company for years.

section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: The relative pronoun can be left out if it is the object of the verb in the relative clause.
section.text1: Simon bought a jacket. We saw (verb) the jacket (object).
section.text1a: Simon bought the jacket that we saw when we went shopping last weekend.
section.text2a: Simon bought the jacket we saw when we went shopping last weekend.

section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: Non-defining relative clauses give extra information which can be left out. Commas are used before and after non-defining relative clauses unless they end a sentence.
section.text1: I've lent my new bike to my brother. I really like the bike
section.text1a: I've lent my new bike, which I really like, to my brother.
section.text2: Cairo is a fascinating city. I lived there for several years.
section.text2a: Cairo, where I lived for several years, is a fascinating city.
section.text3: My brother is coming to stay next weekend. He has just become a pilot.
section.text3a: My brother, who has just become a pilot, is coming to stay next weekend.
section.text4: The village is very pretty. It is on the coast.
section.text4a: The village, which is on the coast, is very pretty.
